- Terry Eastland (author of "From Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice") [states] "Most arguments for affirmative action fall into two categories: remedying past discrimination and promoting diversity".
- Terry Eastland [believes] the founders of affirmative action did not anticipate how the benefits of affirmative action would go to those who did not need it, mostly middle class minorities.
- Terry Eastland [argues] affirmative action carries with it a stigma that can create feelings of self-doubt and entitlement in minorities.
- Terry Eastland [believes] affirmative action is a great risk that only sometimes pays off, and that without it we would be able to compete more freely with one another.
- Thomas Sowell (libertarian economist) [identified] what he says are negative results of affirmative action in his book, "Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study".
- Thomas Sowell [writes] affirmative action policies encourage non-preferred groups to designate themselves as members of preferred groups [i.e., primary beneficiaries of affirmative action] to take advantage of group preference policies.
- Thomas Sowell [writes] affirmative action policies tend to benefit primarily the most fortunate among the preferred group (e.g., upper and middle class blacks), often to the detriment of the least fortunate among the non-preferred groups (e.g., poor white or Asian).
- Thomas Sowell [writes] affirmative action policies reduce the incentives of both the preferred and non-preferred to perform at their best – the former because doing so is unnecessary and the latter because it can prove futile – thereby resulting in net losses for society as a whole.
- Thomas Sowell [writes] affirmative action policies engender animosity toward preferred groups as well.
The second-largest commercial airport is:
- William P. Hobby Airport (former name: Houston International Airport) [operates] short- to medium-haul domestic flights
- William P. Hobby Airport [launchedService] Southwest Airlines (destinations: Mexico, Central America, and the Caribbean)
- William P. Hobby Airport [hasMuseum] 1940 Air Terminal Museum
- William P. Hobby Airport [hasAwards] two awards (categories: top five performing airports in the world, customer service)

- Palermo (population: 51,000) [wasControlledBy] Aragon and Barcelona dynasties (since: 1330)
- Palermo [wasControlledBy] Kingdom of Spain (from: 1479, to: 1713)
- Palermo [wasControlledBy] Kingdom of Spain (from: 1717, to: 1718)
- Palermo [wasControlledBy] Savoy (from: 1713, to: 1717)
- Palermo [wasControlledBy] Savoy (from: 1718, to: 1720)
- Palermo [wasControlledBy] Austria (from: 1720, to: 1734)
In order to explain the common features:
- Sanskrit [isRelatedTo] Indo-European languages
- Indo-Aryan migration theory [explains] common features of Sanskrit and Indo-European languages
- Indo-Aryan migration theory [asserts] original speakers of Sanskrit arrived in India and Pakistan from the north-west
- Indo-Aryan migration theory [asserts] original speakers of Sanskrit arrived in India and Pakistan during the early second millennium BCE
- Indo-Iranian tongues [isRelatedTo] Baltic and Slavic languages
- Indo-European languages [hasVocabularyExchangeWith] Uralic languages
